Generate_script_prompt:
Prompt: Give a quick tech news update script in the style of CNBC techcheck briefing as an example.
        Response: I'm Wall-E, and this is your CNBC techcheck Briefing for Monday April 29th. Tesla is asking shareholders to reinstate CEO Elon Musk's $56 billion pay package, which a Delaware judge voided earlier this year. The judge ruled that the record-setting compensation deal was, quote, deeply flawed. Tesla also saying it would ask shareholders to approve moving the company's incorporation from Delaware to Texas. The company has hired a proxy solicitor and plans to spend millions of dollars to help secure votes for the two proposals. Apple CEO Tim Cook says the company plans to look at manufacturing in Indonesia following a meeting with the country's president, Cook telling reporters following the meeting that he spoke with the president about his desire to see manufacturing there and that he believes in the country. The comments come as Apple is pushed to diversify its supply chain with more manufacturing outside of China in countries such as Vietnam and India. Shares of ASML falling today as the company missed its sales forecast but stuck to its full-year outlook. Net sales fell over 21 percent year-over-year, while net income dropped over 37 percent. ASML is highly important to the semiconductor industry as it builds machines that are required for manufacturing chips globally. Last year, weaker demand for consumer electronics hit chipmakers that produce for those devices, which has in turn impacted ASML. That's all for today. We'll see you back here tomorrow.
        Prompt: Give a quick tech news update script in the style of CNBC techcheck briefing using the following news titles and content. Closely follow how CNBC techcheck chooses context to put into the script, the langauge style and sentence structure. Use the same beginning and ending(including mentioning host Wall-E and Friday November 29), and replace CNBC techcheck briefing to 'AI briefing' 
 ""

Response:
Script:
i'm wall-e, and this is your ai briefing for friday, november 29th.

first up, google is once again in the spotlight as the company faces antitrust concerns from regulators in the european union. the latest investigation could lead to stricter rules around how google operates its advertising services, with officials worried about its overwhelming market power. the tech giant continues to argue that its services benefit consumers and competition, setting the stage for another contentious battle with european authorities.

over to cupertino, apple has announced an unprecedented investment in renewable energy, pledging billions to develop new clean energy projects across multiple continents. tim cook, apple's ceo, emphasized the company's commitment to leading the charge against climate change, stating that these efforts are crucial to achieving their long-term sustainability goals. this move aligns with apple's ongoing strategy to become carbon neutral across its entire supply chain by 2030.

meanwhile, reports from south korea reveal that samsung is gearing up for a major leap forward in smartphone technology. the company plans to introduce next-generation foldable displays that are thinner, lighter, and more durable. market analysts predict this could reinvigorate samsung's position as a leader in innovation, potentially setting a new standard for high-end smartphones in the coming years.

lastly, shares of zoom have taken a slight dip after the video conferencing platform issued a cautious forecast for the upcoming quarter. despite strong user growth during the pandemic, zoom faces increasing competition from tech giants like microsoft and google, who continue to enhance their own communication tools. the company remains optimistic, however, about expanding its market reach through new features and services aimed at enterprise users.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Polished Script:
i'm wall-e, welcoming you to today's tech briefing for friday, november 29th.

first, google is back under the regulatory magnifying glass in the european union. eu regulators have launched another antitrust investigation into google's advertising services, raising concerns about the company's extensive market dominance. the investigation could result in stricter regulations on how google manages its advertising empire. google, in its defense, insists that its services drive consumer benefit and foster competition, setting the stage for yet another contentious standoff with european officials.

now over to cupertino. apple has made headlines with a bold pledge to invest billions in renewable energy projects spanning multiple continents. ceo tim cook highlighted apple's dedication to combating climate change as integral to their long-term sustainability objectives. this colossal investment aligns with apple's rigorous plan to achieve carbon neutrality across its entire supply chain by 2030.

meanwhile, across the globe in south korea, samsung is reportedly preparing for a major innovation in smartphone technology. the tech giant is working on next-generation foldable displays, which promise to be thinner, lighter, and more robust. analysts suggest this advancement could reestablish samsung as a frontrunner in smartphone innovation, potentially setting a new benchmark for premium devices in the years ahead.

lastly, zoom shares have experienced a slight decline following a conservative forecast for the upcoming quarter. despite experiencing robust user growth propelled by the pandemic, zoom is contending with rising competition from tech titans like microsoft and google, who are continually enhancing their own communication platforms. nonetheless, zoom is optimistic about broadening its market presence with new features and services tailored to enterprise clients.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Podcast Title: EP-162 Google's Eu Antitrust Showdown 🔍, Apple's Green Billions 🌍, Samsung's Foldable Future 📱
Podcast Description:
i'm wall-e, presenting today's tech briefing for friday, november 29th. explore the day's leading tech updates:

  • google under eu scrutiny: another antitrust investigation has begun into google's advertising dominance in the eu, which might lead to new regulations. google maintains that its services benefit consumers and encourage competition.
  • apple's renewable energy commitment: apple pledges billions towards global renewable energy projects, aiming for complete carbon neutrality across its supply chain by 2030, as emphasized by ceo tim cook.
  • samsung's foldable tech innovation: samsung is advancing foldable display technology, potentially setting a new standard for smartphones with thinner and more durable designs.
  • zoom's market position: zoom's shares dip slightly amidst competitive pressures from microsoft and google, yet the company is hopeful about expanding its reach with new offerings for enterprises.

catch us tomorrow for further tech insights!
Image Prompt: a dynamic podcast cover image presents an engaging composition symbolizing the central themes of the titles. in the foreground, a large balance scale tilts towards a cluster of digital devices representing google, subtly nodding to the eu antitrust context with a faint overlay of the european union flag in the background. surrounding the scale, lush green forests and wind turbines surge upwards, symbolizing apple's investment in sustainable initiatives, giving a fresh and eco-friendly touch. meanwhile, overhead, sleek, futuristic foldable smartphones unfold like blooming flowers, representing samsung's vision for the future of technology. the overall image fuses corporate intrigue, environmental consciousness, and technological innovation into a single, harmonious visual narrative
